explanation: Answer key for remote management, fork hygiene, and collaboration security.

answerKey.rationale: Remote add/rename/remove commands manage remote aliases.
fetch --prune updates remotes and removes stale tracking refs.
Tracking upstream remotes, fetching, and merging keep forks synced.
Remote-tracking refs update on fetch without impacting local branches.
Regular sync and communication keep shared history aligned.
pull --rebase fetches updates then rebases local commits on top.
Tags can be fetched via --tags, prune-tags, or explicit refspecs.
Staying current with upstream reduces conflict risk.
Rotations, scoped tokens, and credential helpers secure authentication.
push.default simple pushes only the current branch to its matching remote branch.

keyPoints: Manage remotes with add, rename, remove, and set-url commands.
Fork workflows rely on syncing upstream regularly.
Remote-tracking refs update on fetch without merging automatically.
Disciplined sync cadences prevent large integration conflicts.
pull --rebase maintains linear feature branch history.
Fetch tags explicitly to mirror release metadata.
Keep branches current with upstream to minimize rework.
Secure credentials through rotation, least privilege, and helpers.
push.default simple guards against unintended multi-branch pushes.
